The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: some overlap with energy economics and policy analysis, but more international and also more theoreticalin scope. after taking this class, i feel equipped to assess all kinds of energy policies and to compare them to best practices.
Kessiddes is such a nice person and clearly very smart but it was hard to follow him and his slides werethe worst slides I've ever seen.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This is one of the few courses that deeply explores 'Energy' from a variety of different perspectives including policy, social science, engineering and economics. The Professor has a wide and varied experience and is very knowledgeable about all things related to energy in the political realm as well as the technical aspects. I liked the depth of the course and the fact that we looked at specific issues in great detail and I now feel like I actually learned some things that I can apply to situations in real life, especially if I were to take on a role in energy policy or consulting.

Subject area - we definitely need a course on energy policy. And a class that discusses nuclear. Kessides has very good knowedge in utility theory -- more on this with case studies would have been great.
the professor's depth and breadth of knowledge, the discussions in class on days when everybody participated

I really enjoyed the in-class discussions. Dr. Kessides was very open to student questions and would often go off on interesting tangents based on student questions. Despite the tangents, he seemed very able to keep the class on schedule.
learning about energy

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Lectures were a bit dry, they need to be more interactive. Testing should be more frequent to ensure that students actually study the material.

Kessides did not cover some basic energy related policies like RPS, FIT or a carbon tax. These were major oversights I think. We spent too much time on renewables, which isn't his area of expertise.Also, the readings were often posted just hours before class - way too late! The final research paper I think was too long and not very helpful for students in the class. There seemed to be no accountability for the shorter papers, and we never got any of them back. As a result, it was hard to know what he was looking for in the final paper.Class itself was often a bit boring due to lecture style and text-heavy slides, but I do appreciate that he lets students jump in.

the three hour lecture style. would be much better in two 1.5 hour sessions. the teacher should have been more responsive to student feedback on the syllabus in the first couple of weeks to eliminate overlaps with other courses and satisfy curriculum gaps. the reading responses should have real deadlines and readings should be incorporated into in-class lectures and discussions.
Overall this was a very strong course.
the slides and lectures

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A; there was no lab section.
all of it.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is very relevant to my program as am focusing on Energy and Environment and also have a strong interest in Energy Policy in Developing Countries.
filled in some gaps in the energy curriculum. a rare global perspective on energy policy.
Energy policy is my main focus, so this was a perfect fit.
energy issues

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: We need an in-depth course on energy policy that goes into further detail than a survey course like Esty's. It's a critical component of any energy curriculum FES develops.
As part of the energy SIG, we identified gaps in our curriculum and felt that this course would help to fill one such gap.
See above answer.
i wanted to learn more about energy

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.

mostly. i would have liked more concrete examples of international energy policies. e.g. what does germany's feed in tariff look like, why is scandinavia so "green," how did france develop nuclear, etc.
Yes. I especially appreciated the focus on establishing regulatory agencies in developing countries, because that was an area that none of my other coursework had touched on.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: start your paper early... it is LONG
Take it; it's very good!
Finish your reading responses in Spring break.
